Subject: URI delimiters and reserved characters (a [rest-discuss] public-service
 announcement)
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=328589632; y=kLO9OBbd50lcOckyA6VwU7yA0q941RLhtv9D9r5KZdUWmrCz4r4

Andrew Houghton wrote (in
<http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/=
message/11190>):

> [The square brackets] are reserved for scheme specific =
URI specification.

Actually, schemes must adhere to the semantics that RFC=
 3986 prescribes
for the square brackets.

> The ["http" URI scheme] does n=
ot make use of [the square brackets], but does specify [the solidus] as the=
 path segment separator.

Actually, the "http" URI scheme, if we follow RFC=
 2732
(<http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2732.txt>), allows square brackets=
 to
delimit IP-literals. And the "http" URI scheme has nothing to say about=

the solidus because RFC 2396
(<http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2396.txt>,=
 the predecessor to RFC
3986) was definitive about the semantics of the sol=
idus.

> So if you want to use [the square brackets or the solidus] in an [=
"http"] URI you must [percent-encode] those characters.

Actually, the squa=
re brackets and solidus may appear as prescribed. If
percent-encoding takes=
 place, the square brackets and the solidus
disappear and thus they will no=
t be part of a URI.

-- 
Please do not include my address in public replies=
. I will read public
replies on the list.
